event: First known inhabitants, the Saqqaq culture, arrive in Greenland.
Dorset culture replaces Saqqaq; later replaced by Thule people around 1200 AD.
Erik the Red, exiled from Iceland, discovers and names Greenland; begins Norse settlement.
Leif Erikson, son of Erik the Red, sails from Greenland and explores parts of North America (Vinland).
Norse settlements begin to decline due to climate cooling and isolation.
Norse Greenlanders disappear; Inuit cultures continue to thrive.
Danish missionary Hans Egede establishes a mission, beginning Danish colonization.
Treaty of Kiel grants Denmark full control over Greenland after dissolution of Denmark-Norway union.
Greenland becomes an integral part of the Kingdom of Denmark.
During German occupation of Denmark, U.S. assumes defense of Greenland by agreement.
Greenland becomes an official county of Denmark with representation in the Danish parliament.
Greenland granted home rule by Denmark, gaining autonomy over internal affairs.
Greenland withdraws from the European Economic Community (EEC) following a referendum.
Greenland Act expands self-rule, transferring more power from Denmark, including control over natural resources.
Inuit Ataqatigiit party wins election on platform of environmental protection and resource sovereignty.
